Graphical abstract Thirty-five doped and undoped rare earth oxide catalysts were synthesized and tested under identical conditions for the oxidative coupling of methane. While La2O3 was found to be the most active, La2O3 doped with Sr was found to be the most selective. High resolution low energy ion scattering (HR-LEIS) showed that doping with Sr above 2 mole % led to migration of Sr to the surface of the catalyst producing surface (Sr/La) ratios of 2.7 – 4.4 from bulk (Sr/La) ratios of 0.053 and 0.13, respectively. Operando Raman analysis run under OCM conditions identified La2O3 and SrCO3 as the predominant lanthanum and strontium phases during reaction. A bilayer structure comprising a thermally stable Sr-doped La2O3 base covered with a mostly amorphous Sr phase containing SrCO3, SrO and SrO2 was proposed. Selectivity to C2+ for this structure increased with surface Sr content; and SrO2 is believed to be responsible for this effect. Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane Doped lanthanide catalysts X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Operando Raman Surface chemistry 1 Introduction With the significant increase in the amount of methane available from shale gas operations in the United States, the price of this commodity has stayed historically low making methane an ideal feedstock for production of high valued chemicals such as ethylene and propylene. The traditional route to these chemicals from methane has been steam methane reforming (SMR) which first produces synthesis gas (CO + H2) the precursor to methanol. The methanol can then be converted to ethylene using a process developed by Mobil Corporation in the late 1970s. However, this route is expensive relative to steam cracking of ethane for ethylene production and is not an economically viable option in today’s market, especially on the U. S. Gulf Coast which has abundant ethane to use as feed for steam cracking to make ethylene. Based on the pioneering work of Keller and Bhasin at Union Carbide [1], it is possible to convert methane directly into ethylene using a process known as oxidative coupling of methane (OCM); so for the past forty years, scientists have sought the ideal catalyst for this process. To date, however, the yield and selectivity to C2+has been lower than commercially viable and that is the stimulus for this work. Among the most widely studied catalysts for OCM are the rare earth oxides [2–34] either alone or aliovalently doped with alkaline earth oxides (which have been shown to increase their activity and selectivity). There is much disagreement in the literature, however, as to which of these catalysts is best because they have been evaluated at different temperatures, levels of methane and oxygen conversion and residence times. Recent work in our laboratory involved the preparation and testing (under commercially viable OCM conditions) of 35 doped and undoped lanthanide catalysts; and the results indicated clearly that Sr-doped La2O3 is the preferred catalyst for OCM. They also indicated that this catalyst’s activity and selectivity depend significantly on the ratio of Sr to La. Figs. S2 – S22 in the Supporting Information show the effect of doping these lanthanides with alkaline earth oxides on oxygen conversion, methane conversion and C2+ selectivity; and Tables S1 and S2 show the effect of doping at different levels (10 mole % and 5 mole % respectively) on crystal structure. Low doping levels (<2 mole%) allow Sr to substitute into the La2O3 lattice and create oxygen vacancies, which have been shown to increase C2+ selectivity. Levels of strontium above the solubility limit result in formation of a separate Sr phase (as shown in the XRD analyses) which affects both activity and selectivity; and this is the subject of the current study. Whereas the earlier work included in the Supporting Information showed the effect of the catalyst composition on activity and selectivity, the study described here explores in detail the nature of the surface of the catalyst and proposes a new mechanism for reaction that is consistent with observations. 2 Experimental For this study a total of 35 doped and undoped lanthanide catalysts were synthesized by combustion synthesis [35,36]. Catalyst powder so produced was then calcined at 1,000 °C for 6 hours followed by pressing to 15,000 psig in a cold isostatic press and sizing to 40/60 mesh. Approximately 20 mg of each catalyst were tested for OCM activity in a 2.3 mm ID quartz tube reactor under commercially viable conditions (CH4/O2 ratio of 7.4, no diluent and a residence time of ∼ 5 msec). A schematic of the reactor system used is shown in Fig. S1 of the Supporting Information. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was carried out on a Rigaku Miniflex 600 diffractometer using Cu K-α radiation (λ =1.54059 Å) and operated at a tube voltage and current of 40 kV and 15 ma, respectively. A continuous sweep mode was used to collect the data in a 2θ range of 10 – 90° at a speed of 10°/min and a step size of 0.025°. Low background sample holders comprising single crystal silicon wafers were used to produce cleaner diffraction patterns. XRD data were subjected to Rietveld refinement using Rigaku’s PDXL2 software. To complement the XRD analysis, which only looks at bulk properties, surface characterization was performed using High Sensitivity - Low Energy Ion Scattering (HS-LEIS) on an IONTOF Qtac100 instrument. This device, located at Lehigh University, is one of only two in North America and has 3000 times the sensitivity of conventional LEIS instruments. The nature of the active sites in the presence of reactant and product gases (particularly CO, CO2 and H2O) was explored using in-situ (operando) Raman analysis on a Horiba LabRam high resolution spectrometer also located at Lehigh University and equipped with a Linkam CCR1000 in-situ cell and a 532 nm laser. The catalyst samples were first treated (atmospheric pressure) with N2 at 40 sccm and 1,000 °C, then cooled to 525 °C (still under N2). The feed gas was then switched to a mixture of methane and pure oxygen (CH4/O2 = 7.4) at 40 sccm and the temperature was increased from 525 °C to 825 °C in 50 or 75 °C increments. Catalyst basicity was measured by CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2 TPD) using a Hiden CatLab® equipped with a 4 mm quartz tube reactor and a QGA mass spectrometer which continuously analyzed desorbed products. TGA/DSC was carried out on selected samples using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1. Scanning electron micrographs were obtained using a JEOL JSM-7800 F Field Emission Electron Microscope; and surface areas and pore volumes were determined using a Quantachrome Autosorb 6iSA. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization and Testing of Primary Basis Set A major goal of testing these rare earth oxides was to be able to compare their crystalline structures and the effect of regular structural variation on activity and selectivity in the oxidative coupling of methane. In all, 35 doped and undoped oxides (the primary basis set) having the theoretical compositions shown in Table S1 of the Supporting Information were synthesized as described above. For the initial studies, the doping level for all catalysts was arbitrarily chosen as 10 mole% of the lanthanide cation. X-ray diffraction analyses of all 35 catalysts of the primary basis set showed that all of the undoped oxides were single phase structures; and an example diffraction pattern for undoped La2O3 is shown in Fig. 1 . The blue line represents the raw data and the red “plus” symbols represent the Rietveld refinement, which indicated a 100 % pure La2O3 phase. XRD analyses of all 35 catalysts in the basis set are shown in Table S1 in the Supporting Information and confirm that La2O3, Nd2O3 and their doped derivatives are hexagonal, Sm2O3 and its derivatives are monoclinic and the remainder of the oxides and derivatives are cubic. Results from OCM testing of the primary basis set (Supporting Information Figs. S2-S22) showed that 10 mole % Sr doping was superior to that of the other alkaline earth ions; but XRD analyses (Table S1) showed that there was an excess SrO phase apparent suggesting that 10 mole% doping exceeded the solubility limit of Sr for all of the lanthanides. Therefore, another set of seven catalysts having 5 mole% Sr doping was prepared. These comprised La1.9Sr0.1O2.9, Nd1.9Sr0.1O2.9, Sm1.9Sr0.1O2.9, Gd1.9Sr0.1O2.9, Dy1.9Sr0.1O2.9, Er1.9Sr0.1O2.9 and Yb1.9Sr0.1O2.9. Based on the results of testing with these seven catalysts, Sr was again clearly the optimum dopant (Supporting Information Table S2 and Fig. S23); and an additional catalyst was prepared to explore the effect of Sr content on activity and selectivity. This catalyst comprised LaSr0.13Ox (so-called non-stoichiometric). While the OCM results have been compared at length, the exact nature of the excess strontium species and more specifically the nature of the surface of these catalysts has not been described previously; and it is that work that will be presented here. 3.2 Surface and Bulk Characterization of Sr-doped La2O3 3.2.1 Operando Raman Spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy detects molecular vibrations of both bulk and surface species. Utilizing a high temperature flow cell with metered gas flow (either an inert gas or OCM reactants), it is possible to observe changes in the catalyst at temperature and under actual reaction conditions. Operando Raman studies were done initially with pure La2(CO3)3 and SrO phases to explore their individual behaviors in OCM atmospheres; and the resulting spectra are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 respectively. Referring to Fig. 2, La2(CO3)3 at room temperature (RT) gives rise to a triplet of strong vibrational bands at 1088 (s), 1077 (m) and 1053 (m), a band at 760 (m) cm-1 as well as very weak bands in the 500-900 cm-1 region. Heating La2(CO3)3 in flowing N2 to 1,000 °C decomposed La2(CO3)3 to La2O3 with Raman bands at 384 (s) and 191(m) cm-1. La2O3 is known to be a good OCM catalyst; so the temperature was lowered from 1,000 °C to 825 °C (upper end of testing range for OCM catalysts); and the feed gas was changed to an OCM mix having a CH4/O2 ratio of 7.4. As the temperature was lowered to 525 °C under OCM conditions, the La2O3 Raman bands persisted; and there was no evidence of carbonate formation. Thus, it was concluded that La2O3 is the dominant lanthanum phase under OCM reaction conditions. Referring to Fig. 3, the spectrum at room temperature (RT) shows weak vibrations from SrO at 871 (m) and 710 (m) cm-1 as well as a trace of SrCO3 (1,070 cm-1). Heating the SrO reference to 1,000 °C in flowing N2 decomposed the SrCO3; and the weak vibrational bands from SrO disappeared due to thermal broadening as did all other bands upon heating to 1,000 °C in N2. This could also be a result of the transition of SrO to an amorphous phase that is less visible by Raman. However, under an OCM atmosphere containing CO2 at temperatures ranging from 525 °C to 825 °C, only the crystalline SrCO3 is apparent. The SrCO3 band at 1070-1072 cm-1 is much stronger at 525 °C than at 825 °C, again partially because of thermal broadening and partially because the melting point of SrCO3 is 1,494 °C (producing a Tammann temperature of approximately 750 °C) which means that at 825 °C SrCO3 might also be partially amorphous. In general, thermal broadening is felt to be less important in these spectra than the transition from a crystalline to an amorphous phase. Switching the gas from flowing N2 to OCM reaction conditions produced the Raman bands characteristic of SrCO3 in the 825 – 525 °C temperature range. As a result, SrCO3 is believed to be the dominant strontium phase under OCM reaction conditions; although, as will be discussed later, it is believed that strontium peroxide (SrO2) is important as an amorphous surface species which would be more difficult to quantify in Raman. TGA/DSC analysis of La(OH)3 and SrCO3 (which contained a small amount of Sr(OH)2 from exposure to the atmosphere) showed that all species were fully decomposed to La2O3 in air at 1,000 °C but that decomposition of SrCO3 is incomplete at 900 °C (see Supporting Information Figs. S24 and S25). In-situ Raman spectra of the non-stoichiometric catalyst (LaSr0.13Ox) under N2 and OCM reactants are shown in Fig. 4 . The initial Raman spectrum of LaSr0.13Ox under ambient conditions (RT) does not exhibit vibrations from carbonates (1060-1090 cm-1); but Raman bands from La2O3 (835 cm-1, 556 cm-1 and 407 cm-1) as well as SrO (747 cm-1) are present. Heating to 1,000 °C in flowing N2 produced only a band from La2O3 (393 cm-1) and a trace of SrCO3 from a small amount of CO2 present in the line. Switching to OCM reaction conditions and lowering the reaction temperature from 825 °C to 525 °C increased the intensity of the bands from La2O3 and SrCO3 confirming that these are the two dominant species under OCM conditions. In-situ Raman spectra of the stoichiometric catalyst (La1.9Sr0.1O2.9) under N2 and OCM reactants are shown in Fig. 5 . The initial catalyst possessed Raman bands from La2O3 (s), SrCO3 (m) and La2(CO3)3 (w). As before, heating to 1,000 °C in flowing N2 decomposed the carbonates; and only La2O3 was observed (SrO was not visible and this is another indication that at 1,000 °C SrO is probably amorphous). Switching to OCM reaction conditions, cooling the catalyst to 525 °C and then heating from 525 °C to 825 °C (the reverse of the ramp used previously) produced only the Raman bands of La2O3 and SrCO3. Although SrCO3 is expected for the non-stoichiometric LaSr0.13Ox catalyst sample that had an excess Sr phase (as shown by XRD), the presence of SrCO3 in the stoichiometric catalyst, which does not exhibit a second phase by XRD, confirmed that Sr existed as a second phase in that catalyst as well and that there is a strong affinity between CO2 and SrO under OCM reaction conditions. The absence of Raman bands for La2(CO3)3 during OCM confirmed that it was not present. The picture that this paints of the stoichiometric La1.9Sr0.1O2.9 catalyst is one of a La2-xSrxO3-x core (where x < 0.1) with a thin coating of mostly amorphous SrO that cannot be detected by XRD and suggests further that a SrO/SrO2/SrCO3 mixture in intimate contact with La+3 in the lattice may be the catalytically active sites for the OCM reaction, as will be discussed later. XPS and TEM studies are underway that are expected to provide additional information in this area. 3.2.2 High Sensitivity Low Energy Ion Scattering (HS-LEIS) To probe the extent of surface segregation further, we performed high-sensitivity low energy ion scattering (HS-LEIS), which analyzes the outermost surface layer of the catalyst. For this analysis, the probing ion was 5 keV Ne+; and sputter etching was performed with 0.5 keV Ar+. As a rule, a sputter dose of 1 × 1015 ions/cm2 corresponds to the removal of one monolayer (∼0.3 nm). Prior to HS-LEIS analysis, the catalysts were pretreated in a separate chamber in the presence of either Ar (60 minutes at 700 °C) or CH4/O2/He (CH4/O2 = 7.2, 60 minutes at 700 °C followed by 30 minutes at 570 °C) and then moved to the high vacuum chamber without exposure to ambient conditions. Results of removal of approximately 12 layers (∼ 3.6 nm) from the non-stoichiometric catalyst pretreated only in Ar produced the results shown in Fig. 6 . It is visually evident that, on the outermost surface of the catalyst, the Sr/La ratio is greater than the bulk ratio of 0.13 indicating surface Sr enrichment. Fig. 7 shows the Sr/La found in this analysis as a function of depth measured from the surface. As monolayers of catalyst were removed, the Sr signal decreased and the La signal increased, as expected. These data were constructed by subtracting an interpolated linear background from the spectral region of interest and then integrating for the area of the resultant peak. While atomic sensitivity does not vary much among Sr and La, it does vary; and we did not have good sensitivity factors for them. As a result, any values shown in the profile plots for Sr/La would misrepresent the actual atomic ratio by a ratio of these factors and should be taken as indicative at best. Fig. 8 shows a graphical representation of the surface removal process for this catalyst. After removal of 12 layers from the non-stoichiometric catalyst, the Sr/La ratio was found to be ∼ 0.57 which was closer to the bulk ratio of 0.13. Prior to sputtering, the Sr/La ratio on the outermost layer was 4.4, suggesting a significant enrichment of Sr on the surface. The HS-LEIS spectra obtained with the Ne+ probe from the non-stoichiometric catalyst exposed to OCM feed yielded strong peaks for Sr and La with the same characteristics as before (see Fig. 9 ). The signal ratio of Sr/La from the outermost surface layer, however, was now found to be ∼2.0, which is about 50% less than after just Ar treatment. It is known that CO2 is produced by OCM catalysts at much lower temperatures than C2+ molecules; and, as a result, treatment of the catalyst at 570 °C would have exposed the catalyst to mostly CO, CO2 and H2O. This reduced signal ratio of Sr/La suggests that, since Sr is less surface-enriched after the OCM treatment, the formation of SrCO3 from reaction with CO2 produced during low temperature OCM may have limited the mobility of the SrO and lessened the surface coverage that could occur in the absence of CO2. After removal of 12 layers, the Sr/La ratio was found to be ∼ 0.48 (see Fig. 7 red triangles) In order to compare the surfaces of the stoichiometric catalyst (La1.9Sr0.1O2.9) under different pretreatment gases, the Ar exposure was carried out at 550 °C rather than 700 °C; and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . The signal ratio of Sr/La after Ar treatment was found to be ∼2.7 in the outermost surface layer, which is ∼40% lower than for non-stoichiometric LaSr0.13Ox with excess Sr treated with Ar. This lower Sr/La signal ratio is consistent with the lower amount of Sr in the stoichiometric sample, but indicates that Sr is still significantly surface enriched on the stoichiometric catalyst after treatment in Ar. With sputtering, the depth profile trends for Sr and La of the stoichiometric La1.9Sr0.1O3 were essentially identical to that previously found for the non-stoichiometric catalyst, with the Sr signal decreasing and the La signal increasing with depth from the outermost surface (see Fig. 11 ). After removal of 12 layers, the Sr/La signal ratio was found to be 0.30. These trends again confirm the enrichment of Sr and depletion of La in the surface region. Importantly, it demonstrates that the outermost surface layer of even the stoichiometric La1.9Sr0.1O2.9 catalyst sample after the Ar treatment extensively consists of surface SrO, which is probably present as a two-dimensional amorphous overlayer approximately 3-5 nm thick (since it did not appear in the XRD analysis and since the Sr/La ratio approached the bulk level at 3.6 nm). The HS-LEIS spectra obtained with the Ne+ probe from the stoichiometric catalyst exposed to OCM feed yielded strong peaks for Sr and La with the same characteristics as before (see Fig. 12 ). The signal ratio of Sr/La from the outermost surface layer, however, was now found to be ∼2.1, which is about 22% less than after just Ar treatment. Removal of 12 layers by sputtering produced a Sr/La ratio of 0.37 (see Fig. 11). 3.3 Structural Implications It has been confirmed in the present study that La2O3 and Nd2O3 both have hexagonal structures, Sm2O3 has a monoclinic structure and the lanthanide oxides with the smaller ionic radii all have cubic structures, indicating that there are crystallographic structural effects on catalyst activity that are important. Palmer and coworkers [37], using DFT GGA (PW96) for periodic calculations for surfaces and bulk study and the Amsterdam density functional (ADF) code with the exchange correlation potential and (STO) basis set of triple-ζ for cluster/adsorbate models, suggested that La2O3 is made up of two pairs of double hexagonal layers (La-O’-O’-La) that are connected by an oxygen (O”n)2n- layer, making the structure more susceptible to reaction with water which has a positive effect on methane activation (as shown in Fig. S26) and consequent exfoliation. Interestingly, atomistic computer simulations [38] of undoped La2O3 suggest that (1) the (001) surface is the most stable, (2) the majority of the defects are Frenkel disorders, (3) oxygen readily diffuses from the bulk phase to the surface and (4) surface peroxide groups (O2 2-) are theoretically stable. The picture of the optimum OCM catalyst that these data support, then, is one of a Sr-doped La2O3 base (1-2% Sr doped into a single phase structure as suggested by Borchert and Baerns [39]) with excess Sr on the surface (as SrO, SrO2 and/or SrCO3 under OCM conditions); and this is consistent with results of a recently published meta-analysis [40] of 1,802 catalysts tested for the oxidative coupling of methane which suggested that the optimum OCM catalyst has two critical features - a thermally stable oxide support and a thermodynamically stable carbonate phase. Based on our data, it appears that methane activation occurs on the single-phase Sr-doped La2O3 support surface, which is known to have oxygen vacancies as a result of aliovalent doping of Sr+2 for La+3 as well as on the Sr enriched layer which does not exhibit oxygen vacancies. In this scenario, as the Sr-doped La2O3 surface is overlaid with more SrO (during catalyst preparation) and/or SrO2 and SrCO3 (during OCM reactions), activity declines and selectivity increases. Further, based on the combined XRD and Raman analyses, we hypothesize that the initial excess SrO is mostly amorphous; but under OCM conditions where CO, CO2 and H2O are all produced, it is at least partially amorphous SrO2 and semi-crystalline SrCO3. TGA analysis (Fig. S25) showed that SrCO3 began to decompose around 825 °C and was fully decomposed by 1,050 °C, which is in the range of actual OCM catalyst temperature when adiabatic temperature rise is taken into account. [41] So it is fair to say that the catalyst surface composition is in dynamic equilibrium and at times will contain La+3 – O-2, O-, O2 2-, Sr(OH)2, SrO2 and SrO in addition to SrCO3. The role of the Sr doped La2O3 appears to be straightforward. Using the hybrid DFT B3LYP with the aug‐cc‐pVDZ basis set for H, C, and O and MWB28 pseudopotential based basis set for La, for equilibrium geometries and vibrational frequencies calculations for DFT and coupled cluster calculations, Cong and coworkers [31] studied the activation of methane by four strontium-doped lanthanum oxide clusters [LaSrO3, La2SrO4(OH), La3SrO6 and La5SrO9] that all had radical character (as a result of the Sr doping) and concluded that the energy barrier for abstraction of hydrogen from methane followed the order O• << Sr-O < La-O. That is, Sr-O is more active than La-O for hydrogen abstraction in these clusters. Interestingly, SrCO3 was not considered in this analysis; however, previous work [42] by the same authors concluded that the Lewis acid-Bronsted base pair, La+3- O2-, was the most active for the activation of methane; although it was also the most susceptible to formation of stable carbonates by reaction with CO2 in the OCM products. We have shown by in-situ Raman analysis that no lanthanum carbonate was formed in the Sr-doped La2O3 catalysts synthesized in our program under the conditions studied. The role of water is equally important; and water produced at temperatures < 500 °C can form surface hydroxyls during reactor startup. Interestingly, the reactivity of lanthanide oxides toward water to form hydroxides has been found to occur more readily with hexagonal lanthanides having larger ionic radii (La2O3 and Nd2O3) but to be imperceptible for lanthanides with smaller ionic radii (Dy2O3 to Lu2O3). [43] Consistent with this, XRD analyses of catalysts from the basis set of the current study that had been exposed to humid air in the laboratory for several months showed that La2O3 and Nd2O3 were fully hydrolyzed, Sm2O3 contained approximately 50% Sm(OH)3, while Gd2O3, Dy2O3, Er2O3 and Yb2O3 were single phase oxides with no trace of hydroxides. Dehydration of La(OH)3 in an inert atmosphere has been shown to proceed through a well-defined LaOOH intermediate and is essentially complete by 420 °C [44]. However, in the presence of water vapor produced from the OCM reaction at temperatures much higher than 420 °C, there will be surface hydroxyl groups that affect reaction; and Campbell and coworkers [7] found that hydrothermally treated La2O3 had a significantly higher activity than the next highest oxide (Nd2O3) in the series of lanthanide oxides. Fig. S26 shows methyl radical generation (a measure of activity) replotted from that study for just the lanthanide elements evaluated in the current study. As stated previously, it has been suggested that one reason for enhanced activity in these catalysts is the strong basicity exhibited by La2O3 [45,46] ; and testing of seven undoped single phase lanthanide oxides by CO2 TPD in the current study showed that La2O3 was considerably more basic than the other lanthanides (Supporting Information Fig. S27). It was also found that doping with even the most basic of the alkaline earth oxides (BaO) resulted in a lowering of the basicity from that of undoped La2O3. So La2O3 fulfills the qualification of a thermally stable oxide and is the most basic of all of the lanthanides (doped or undoped). Operando Raman analyses in the current study confirmed that lanthanum exists in only the oxide form (and not the carbonate) during operation under OCM reaction conditions. The second criterion for an optimum catalyst is the presence of a thermodynamically stable carbonate phase; and, while alkali metal oxides like Li2O and Na2O are very basic and have been shown to work well as additives in short term OCM experiments [47], their carbonates are not thermodynamically stable; and they volatilize over time. While alkaline earth carbonates are less volatile, they are much less effective for OCM alone [48] and all of them do not meet the criterion of thermodynamic stability. Magnesium carbonate decomposes at temperatures below those typical of OCM reactions; and, while BaO, SrO and CaO all form reasonably stable carbonate phases, BaCO3 is too stable and results in both lower activity and selectivity [49]. Ca and Sr doped La2O3 are very similar in performance, with the Sr doped catalyst having a higher C2+ selectivity. 3.4 The Optimum Rare Earth Oxide Catalyst The optimum catalyst identified in the current study, then, has been shown by in-situ Raman to contain both a thermally stable oxide phase (Sr-doped La2O3) and a thermodynamically stable carbonate phase (SrCO3). However, the amount of Sr in the structure is critical in that it has a profound effect on the catalytic mechanism (activity and selectivity). It is well known that aliovalent doping of metal oxides with alkaline earth oxides to produce p-type semiconductors creates oxygen vacancies which increase the oxygen ion conductivity. This, in turn, has been shown to increase the C2+ yield and selectivity. [39,50] For these published studies (with La2O3) the maximum Sr solubility seems to occur between approximately 1 and 6 mole% Sr [21,51] and results in a maximum selectivity to C2+, which decreases with further Sr doping. Calculations for doping of alkaline earth oxides in La2O3 [38] show a minimum energy of solution for Sr; and, interestingly, the energy of solution mirrors the trend of Tammann temperatures for these materials (see Fig. 13 ) all of which suggests that, depending on the sintering temperature used to prepare the catalyst, Sr in some form is mobile and can easily migrate to ultimately form a surface layer. If only oxygen ion vacancies determined catalyst performance, then addition of Sr above its solubility limit would suggest that the performance of the catalyst should be diminished as suggested in the cited papers; however this is only partially the case. In the current study, where T90 is the temperature at which 90% of the oxygen in the feed is consumed and is used as a measure of activity, as the Sr/La ratio was increased, the activity declined (i.e. the T90 increased) but the selectivity to C2+ increased significantly (see Fig. 14 ). The question is why. One possible answer is that, when Sr+2 reaches its maximum solubility in La2O3 (which in the current study was estimated to be about 5 mole%, but in an earlier study by Choudhary and coworkers [49] was estimated to be about 2%), we see the onset of a second phase (SrO) in the XRD pattern. Catalysts in the current study were routinely calcined at a minimum of 1,000 °C during synthesis (often to 1,100 or 1,200 °C); and because of the adiabatic temperature rise seen in OCM [41] at CH4/O2 ratios less than about 8, the actual catalyst temperature during reaction can approach or exceed ∼1,200 °C at which point, because it has the lowest Tammann temperature of all of the alkaline earth oxides, SrO is sufficiently mobile to migrate to the surface of the La2O3. Under OCM conditions SrO is partially converted to SrCO3 and SrO2, both of which are more mobile than SrO. This resultant surface enrichment of Sr was observed by Conway and coworkers [17] ; however, at bulk Sr/La ratios comparable to those in the current study, the surface concentration measured by XPS (which probes the top 5 nm of the surface) in their study was far lower than in our study. For instance, at (Sr/La)bulk of 0.06, these authors obtained a (Sr/La)surface of 0.47; whereas, with our stoichiometric catalyst having a (Sr/La)bulk of 0.05, we observed a (Sr/La)surface of 2.7 by High Sensitivity - Low Energy Ion Scattering in the first monolayer (∼0.3 nm). For our non-stoichiometric catalyst having a (Sr/La)bulk of 0.13, we observed a (Sr/La)surface of 4.4; whereas, for a much higher (Sr/La)bulk of 0.36, these authors observed a (Sr/La)surface of only 0.59 by XPS. It is believed that these differences are due to the fact that XPS averaged the top ∼5 nm of the surface, whereas HS-LEIS measured the composition of the top 0.3 nm and probed sequentially down to ∼4 nm in 13 layers showing a gradual decrease from the surface ratio to the bulk ratio. 3.5 Mechanistic Considerations The structural differences between La2O3 and Sr-doped La2O3 described above have been shown to have a significant impact on both activity and selectivity of these catalysts when used in OCM; and this further suggests a difference in mechanisms between the two. Fig. 15 shows a schematic of the surface of undoped La2O3. Since catalytic activity is believed to be, in part, related to the number of defects in mixed metal oxides, this cannot explain the high activity of this catalyst, as the concentration of such defects is relatively low [38]. Also, since La2O3 is a stoichiometric oxide, there are no innate oxygen vacancies; so the migration of oxygen ions through the lattice should also be low. Therefore, in the absence of such defects and vacancies, some other aspect of the surface of the catalyst must be responsible for the unusually high activity seen in undoped La2O3. It is widely believed that the first step in the OCM process is abstraction of hydrogen from methane by the strongly basic lattice oxygen (O2-) to form a surface hydroxyl group and a surface methyl anion [39,46,52]. The methyl anion can then lose an electron to form a methyl radical and desorb to the gas phase where it can react with another methyl radical to form ethane as shown schematically in Fig. 15. Since undoped La2O3 is an insulator, it cannot accept an electron; so it is logical to assume that the electron is available to be transferred to another entity. Kazansky and coworkers [53,54] proposed that gas phase oxygen can adsorb on a catalyst surface and be reduced in the following sequence, each step requiring either one or two electrons. O 2 ( g ) ↔ O 2 ( a d s ) ↔ O 2 - ↔ O 2 2 - ↔ 2 O - ↔ 2 O 2 - Subsequent reaction of surface hydroxyls forms water which desorbs and an oxygen vacancy as shown in the equation below [55]. 2 ( O H ) - → O 2 - + □ + H 2 O where □ is a lattice oxygen vacancy. Methyl radicals can also react with lattice oxygen and an oxygen vacancy to form methoxide ions where represents an oxygen vacancy associated with an electron. The methoxide ions are the precursors for CO and CO2 and, in part, explain why these oxides are produced at much lower temperatures than C2+, as shown in the current study and by Liu and coworkers [56]. But, the abstraction of hydrogen by lattice oxygen ( O 2 - ) from methane to form a surface hydroxyl species and a gas phase methyl radical has been shown to be endothermic with a high activation barrier, while reaction between methane and either O - or O 2 2 - to produce the same products is exothermic with a low activation barrier [24]. Interestingly, Palmer and coworkers, using DFT calculations, have determined that hydrogen binds with the upper exposed oxygen of the peroxide pair with an adsorption energy 52 kcal/mol more exothermic than with an O - site [37] and offered a plausible mechanism for reaction of methane with surface peroxide oxygens. A similar result was obtained experimentally using Sm2O3 [57,58], although, as has been shown previously, the monoclinic structure of Sm2O3 is not as effective as the hexagonal structure of either La2O3 or Nd2O3. Aliovalent doping of La2O3 with alkaline earth cations, and particularly Sr, changes the oxide chemistry substantially. First, doping with a lower valent ion creates a p-type semiconductor with oxygen vacancies and electron holes that are not present in La2O3. Oxygen can easily diffuse from the bulk to the surface through these vacancies as lattice oxygen is lost as H2O or COx during OCM reactions. This doping effect is not small and only a few atomic percent dopant ions are needed for the full effect. For instance, Cheng and coworkers [59] have shown that the energy barrier for methane activation to methyl radicals over α-Fe2O3 was lowered from 2.0 eV to 1.4 eV by the creation of only 2.4 atomic percent oxygen vacancies; and Borchert and Baerns [39] showed that as little as 1 % Sr substituted into La2O3 was sufficient to increase the C2+ selectivity from 66 to 76%, similar to the results obtained in the current study. Second, and more important, Sr has been found to migrate to the surface and change the nature of the active catalytic sites that CH4 and O2 interact with during OCM reactions. We have shown in the current study that, even for the stoichiometric version of Sr-doped La2O3 with a hypothetical formula of La1.9Sr0.1O2.9 and a bulk Sr/La ratio of 0.053, which appeared to be single phase by XRD, the Sr/La ratio at the surface was 2.7. This suggests a surface structure more like that shown in Fig. 16 . The importance of this layered structure is that surface chemistry is controlled more by the Sr species than the La2O3; but the thermally stable lanthanum oxide support needs to be there in order for the catalyst to function properly [60]. As the strontium content of the catalyst is increased, more of the surface is covered by Sr species and more La2O3 sites are occluded, changing the chemistry from that controlled by the lanthanum surface peroxides to that controlled by the strontium surface peroxides. There are also no oxygen vacancies in the Sr phase, meaning that any chemistry promoted by the O 2 - lattice oxygen in La2O3 would not occur on the Sr phase. This results in a deterioration of activity (a higher T90) and an improvement in C2+ selectivity as shown in Fig. 14. Rather than surface peroxides on La2O3, as proposed by Palmer and coworkers, it is now possible to propose surface peroxides based on SrO2, which can behave in a similar fashion but are more selective. Using a pulsed reactor technique, Otsuka and coworkers [58] showed that oxidative coupling reactions to form C2H6 occurred over SrO2 at temperatures > 673 °K and suggested that the peroxide anions were responsible for the activation of methane. If this were strictly true, then we would have expected the activity of our layered catalyst to have been greater than La2O3, which it was not. Unfortunately the chemistry described by the Otsuka group only occurred in the absence of oxygen, implying that the active oxygen species could not be created from gas phase oxygen, which is unlike the mechanism being proposed here. Looking at Fig. 16, then, we propose that CH4 reacts over any exposed Sr-doped La2O3 sites in the same manner as described above and in the literature [16,17,25,51,61]. Oxygen lost as H2O or COx (shown in the figure as an oxygen vacancy), is replenished either by gas phase oxygen or by diffusion of lattice oxygen from the bulk to the surface. Methane can also react with SrO2 at the surface to produce similar products along with SrO2-H which can lose water to form SrO and diffuse back to the La2O3 interface where it can react with lattice oxygen ions diffusing through the bulk and reform the SrO2 to regenerate the active species. It is proposed that SrO2 diffusion through the surface Sr phase is easier because the latter is amorphous, which explains why it cannot be accounted for fully by x-ray diffraction or in-situ Raman. A Raman spectrum (taken at room temperature) of a sample of SrCO3 sintered at 1,200 °C for 60 hrs to form pure SrO showed no bands at all (see Supporting Information Fig. S28) compared to that of fresh SrCO3 and is consistent with the operando Raman results at 1,000 °C shown in Fig. 4. It should be appreciated that any number of species could co-exist on the surface of the Sr phase including but not limited to SrO, SrO2, Sr(OH)2 and SrCO3, although these could be in very low concentrations and would be less visible by bulk techniques such as XRD and Raman. To explore this further, XPS and TEM studies are currently underway and are expected to be included in future publications. Therefore, the role of SrO2 is critical to the activity and selectivity of these catalysts; and the following is presented in support of this concept. Otsuka and coworkers [57,58] were some of the first to suggest that peroxide ions ( O 2 2 - ) were very reactive for the activation of methane at relatively low temperatures (<673 K). DeWaal and coworkers [62] demonstrated that SrO and SrO2 formed a solid solution at 25 °C; and since the melting points of SrO2 and SrO are 215 °C and 2,531 °C respectively, it is conceivable that this solid solution is a minimum melting point eutectic, where the SrO2 is an amorphous phase dissolved in the SrO. Middleburgh and coworkers [63] found using atomic scale simulations that the enthalpy for formation of BaO2 was strongly negative while that for the formation of SrO2 was only slightly negative. For Ca and Mg the enthalpy was positive. These authors calculated that BaO2 decomposed at roughly 1,175 °K (902 °C) whereas SrO2 decomposed at around 800 °K (527 °C). These are rough approximations; and the calculated decomposition temperatures can vary with the composition of the gaseous environment around the catalyst. They may explain, however, why Sr-doped La2O3 is superior to Ba-doped La2O3 for OCM. Dupin and coworkers [64] used XPS to characterize alkaline earth metal oxides and hydroxides and for the first time found well-differentiated binding energies in the O 1s spectra for SrO, Sr(OH)2 and SrO2 of 527.7 eV, 530.4 eV and 531.1 eV respectively. Finally, Palmer and coworkers [37] postulated a mechanism for the oxidative coupling of methane that invoked the energetically favored reactivity of peroxide species located on the surface of La2O3. In this case the peroxides were formed by the dissociative adsorption of molecular oxygen forming a pair of peroxide sites on the surface. These peroxides abstracted H from CH4 forming gas phase CH3• radicals which coupled to form C2H6. Elimination of water from the catalyst surface regenerated the peroxide species. In the current study, it is postulated that SrO picks up oxygen from the lattice at the SrO/doped La2O3 interface, as shown in Fig. 16, to form SrO2 which, because of its lower melting point is easily dissolved into the SrO phase. We further postulate that the formation of SrCO3 occurs primarily at the surface of this phase and hinders transport of reactive gaseous species to the exterior surface but that, because of the decomposition of SrCO3 as shown by TGA analysis, this is a dynamic situation so that the actual surface comprises a complex mixture of SrO, SrO2, Sr(OH)2 and SrCO3. While not exactly for the same catalyst, XPS analysis of 5 mole % Sr-doped CeO2 in a companion study to the one presented here study showed that the Sr 3d spectrum could be deconvoluted into these four species as shown in the Supporting Information Fig. S29. Similar effects have been observed in solid oxide fuel cells containing La1-xSrxCo0.2Fe0.2O3-δ cathodes. Yu and coworkers [65] found that, in a gaseous atmosphere containing 30% CO2 annealed at 800 °C for 9 hours, Sr migrated to the surface and resulted in an RMS surface roughness increase from 0.16 nm in the unannealed sample to 100 nm in the annealed sample. More importantly this surface structure was shown to be primarily SrO with a thin coating of SrCO3; and Li and coworkers [66] showed for this same cathode material that surface SrCO3 improved the chemical oxygen surface exchange coefficient by up to a factor of 100 by lowering the O2 dissociation barrier from 1.01 eV to 0.33 eV. The possible role of SrO2 in OCM catalysis is, however, not without detractors; and several studies in recent years [67,68] suggest that CH4 does not react with SrO2 to form CH3 radicals. However we would point out that there are major differences between the results reported in those studies and those reported here. Specifically, both of the cited references studied only undoped La2O3 using DFT; and no experimental data supported their conclusions. It is well known that the introduction of as little as 1 mole % Sr into La2O3 creates oxygen vacancies that significantly affect the performance of the catalyst, as we have pointed out. Borchert and Baerns [39] determined that the oxygen anion conductivity of 1 mole % Sr doped La2O3 was two orders of magnitude greater than for La2O3 alone. Failure to account for this will significantly affect the DFT calculations. At 298 °K Chu and coworkers [67], using the hybrid DFT-B3LYP method with a relativistic effective core potential (ECP) for La (aVDZ) for geometry optimization followed by single point energy at the CCSD(T) level with the aug-cc-pVQZ for potential energy surfaces calculations, concluded that the rate of methane activation on the O2− site of La4O6 and La6O9 clusters was 6 − 14 orders of magnitude faster than on the O 2 2 - site of La4O7 and La6O10 ; but at 1,073 °K that rate was only faster by 1 − 4 orders of magnitude. So the temperature effect on the reactivity is substantial. An operating temperature of 1073 °K, however, is still low for OCM, where the actual catalyst temperature (due to the adiabatic temperature rise on light-off) more likely exceeds 1,200 °K. Interestingly, the second cited study [68] was carried out at 823 °K (550 °C) which is far below the operating temperature of OCM. So the effect of temperature is very important; and even theoretical studies must be done at meaningful temperatures for OCM. In addition, Wang and coworkers [68], using DFT-PBE for La2O3 and DFT-B3LYP (6-31G* basis set) for gas phase computation, invoked a bridging mechanism for the La-O pair, where a CH3 − fragment is adsorbed between two adjacent La atoms and a H + fragment is adsorbed at the top site on the O atom. The absence of a lattice oxygen, due to aliovalent doping, with which to form a bridge will significantly affect this conclusion. 4 Conclusions In order to compare the performance of rare earth oxides (both alone and doped with alkaline earth oxides) for the oxidative coupling of methane, a total of thirty-five catalysts were prepared by combustion synthesis and tested for OCM activity and selectivity at a CH4/O2 ratio of 7.4 and an average residence time of 5 msec. The average crystallite size of catalysts made by this approach was < 50 nm as shown by SEM, although the smaller primary particles were fused together by the heat produced during combustion. The rare earth elements selected covered the range of ionic radii from La (the largest) to Yb (the smallest). OCM testing showed that undoped La2O3 was by far the most active (i.e. had the lowest T90 light-off temperature) but was not the most selective. Doping with Mg, Ca, Sr and Ba showed that Sr was clearly the most effective dopant, increasing the C2+ selectivity from 63 % to 73 % over undoped La2O3. Doping with Ba resulted in slightly lower selectivity. Maximum methane conversion with Sr-doped La2O3 ranged from 18.5-19.0 % whereas it was 14.0 -14.5% for the Ba-doped oxide. X-ray diffraction analysis of each catalyst showed that La2O3 and Nd2O3 were both single phase hexagonal lattices while Sm2O3 was monoclinic and Gd2O3, Dy2O3, Er2O3 and Yb2O3 were all cubic. Doping of 10 mole % alkaline earth oxides into these lanthanides resulted in single phase structures for the smaller cations (Mg and Ca) but typically multi-phase structures with the larger cations (Sr and Ba). Of all the catalysts tested, Sr-doped La2O3 produced the best overall OCM results. Analysis of three Sr-doped La2O3 catalysts with different Sr/La ratios (0.053, 0.1 and 0.5) showed that the maximum solubility for Sr was 2 to 5 mole % and that excess Sr appeared as a second phase [SrO, SrO2, Sr(OH)2 or SrCO3], depending on the atmosphere it was exposed to. The amount of Sr in each catalyst as measured by XRD was typically smaller than the calculated bulk composition, suggesting that some of the Sr present in the second phase was amorphous. Operando Raman analysis under OCM conditions (800-900 °C) showed that the only lanthanum phase was La2O3 (i.e. there was no lanthanum carbonate present) whereas the only strontium phase was SrCO3; however, Raman, like XRD, is a bulk technique and does not measure the concentration of species just on the surface. Nor does Raman easily detect amorphous phases, as indicated by its inability to pick up SrO at room temperature in a sample of SrCO3 that had been decomposed at 1,200 °C and cooled. To complement the Raman study, high sensitivity low energy ion scattering (HS-LEIS) analysis was used to analyze the top 15 molecular layers of catalysts with two different bulk Sr/La ratios (0.053 and 0.13) and showed a significant surface migration of Sr from the bulk to the surface, resulting in a Sr/La ratio for the two catalysts of 2.77 and 4.4 respectively. Based on these data, a new mechanism has been proposed for Sr-doped La2O3 wherein (1) a thermally stable first phase comprising Sr-doped La2O3 with a maximum of 1-2 mole % Sr substituted into the lattice provides higher activity (as measured by T90) through the direct interaction of CH4 and O2 with lattice oxygen, surface peroxides and oxygen vacancies in the La2O3 and (2) a thermodynamically stable second phase comprising a mixture of SrO, Sr(OH)2, SrO2 and SrCO3 that is primarily amorphous and that serves to enhance oxygen transport from the base phase to the surface and provides a higher selectivity. Thus, each phase has a primary function; and, as more Sr is added to the catalyst, the surface becomes covered with more of the second (high Sr) phase and both the light-off temperature and the selectivity increase. Additional studies using HRTEM and XPS are currently underway to probe the exact nature of the surface species in order to optimize the formulation of these Sr-doped La2O3 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Thirty-five doped and undoped rare earth oxide catalysts were synthesized and tested under identical conditions for the oxidative coupling of methane. While La2O3 was found to be the most active, La2O3 doped with Sr was found to be the most selective. High resolution low energy ion scattering (HR-LEIS) showed that doping with Sr above 2 mole % led to migration of Sr to the surface of the catalyst producing surface (Sr/La) ratios of 2.7 – 4.4 from bulk (Sr/La) ratios of 0.053 and 0.13, respectively. Operando Raman analysis run under OCM conditions identified La2O3 and SrCO3 as the predominant lanthanum and strontium phases during reaction. A bilayer structure comprising a thermally stable Sr-doped La2O3 base covered with a mostly amorphous Sr phase containing SrCO3, SrO and SrO2 was proposed. Selectivity to C2+ for this structure increased with surface Sr content; and SrO2 is believed to be responsible for this effect.
coredata.dc:title: The Effect of Strontium Content on the Activity and Selectivity of Sr-Doped La2O3 Catalysts in Oxidative Coupling of Methane
